name: Badgeholder Onchain Analysis
description:
The "Badgeholder Onchain Analysis" project is part of our submission to the Optimism retro funding!
As a dedicated research team, we are committed to providing comprehensive and insightful analyses within the ecosystem. Our current focus is on understanding the engagement and activity levels of Badgeholders across both superchain and non-superchain networks.
Our project delves deep into various aspects of on-chain activities, comparing Badgeholders with non-Badgeholders across different metrics. We analyze transaction count percentiles, category engagement, and application usage, providing a detailed view of user behaviour and preferences within the ecosystem. Our findings highlight key differences in transaction volumes, application preferences, and engagement levels across different user segments, offering valuable insights into the community's dynamics.
A significant aspect of our research is the integration with Farcaster, where we examine the level of cross-platform engagement among Badgeholders. Additionally, we explore the advanced engagement of Badgeholders by analyzing their smart contract deployment activities.

grants.details:
https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/ecosystem-contributions/issues/191#issuecomment-2196648905

The required project was completed and submitted using the link provided above.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
Our analysis measures the participation and behavior of Badgeholders in the Superchain ecosystem, specifically focusing on their transaction activities across networks like OP Mainnet, Base, Zora, and Mode. It also examines their engagement in decentralized applications (DEXs), token transfers, and social platforms like Farcaster. 

A key insight is the relatively low activity level of Badgeholders compared to Non-Badgeholders, particularly in areas like DEX trading and smart contract deployment. Additionally, the analysis tracks how Badgeholders' preferences for Ethereum transactions and limited cross-chain activity impact their overall engagement with Optimism's governance processes. 

This helps identify where governance structures may need to be adjusted to include better and activate Badgeholders, ensuring their participation grows alongside the broader ecosystem.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
The Optimism Collective has benefitted most from this analysis, gaining valuable insights into Badgeholder behavior that inform strategies to increase engagement. For example, understanding that Badgeholders are more active on Ethereum but less engaged with smart contract deployment helps the Collective target these users with specific governance initiatives. 

Furthermore, the findings around Farcaster connections show the importance of social engagement within this group, which can shape future governance outreach and participation efforts. The insights have also helped governance teams refine their strategies for promoting cross-chain activity and diversifying user engagement. This research will also guide the future selection of new Badgeholders for the Citizen House by identifying gaps and ensuring the House becomes more inclusive and representative of the entire user profile within the Collective, promoting a well-rounded governance structure.

name: Syntra
description:
Syntra is a delegate dashboard that simplifies DAO governance by streamlining drafting, decision-making, and management with calendar integration.

In the evolving world of decentralized governance, DAOs have become central to decision-making across Web3. Yet, for many delegates, the tools and processes available often feel fragmented, isolated, and hard to navigate. Weâ€™ve experienced these challenges firsthand, not just as developers but as participants in various DAOs.

Syntra is a delegate dashboard born from this realization: governance doesnâ€™t need an isolated toolâ€”it requires an integrated solution focused on people, the ones driving these organizations forward.

Shift in Focus: From Tools to People

For too long, DAO tooling has been focused on solving specific issuesâ€”one tool for proposals, another for voting, and yet another for analytics. The result? A fragmented experience that leaves participants, both newcomers and experienced teams, struggling to piece together a coherent workflow.

Our Approach

We knew there had to be a better way, so we asked: What if we could give DAO participants a head start? What if we could streamline these processes, so they can focus on what really mattersâ€”making impactful decisions?. Our target user base varies from newcomers to professional delegates leading teams of 10+ members.

For newcomers: Syntra lowers the barriers to entry, making it easier to draft proposals, post comments, participate in discussions, vote, and analyze governance activity.
For professional organizations: It facilitates coordination and collaboration, providing role-based access and tracking tools to streamline internal processes.
By integrating many of the existing tools within the DAO ecosystem, we help delegates manage governance processes more efficiently, improving not just individual contributions but also team-based workflows.

links.name: Syntra
links.description:
Starting from the final MVP release, the project will be open-source. It is not intended for profit, as it is a public good. The announcement will be made in the forum communication thread:
https://gov.optimism.io/t/request-for-feedback-syntra-setting-a-new-standard-for-dao-participation/8878

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Syntra simplifies key governance tasks for OptimismDAO Delegates, improving efficiency and decision-making. It also helps with the onboarding of new participants lowering the barrier to entry.

"### **A Day in the Life of an OptimismDAO Delegate with Syntra**

- ***Efficient Proposal Creation***
	- *Delegates start their day by accessing a user-friendly dashboard and draft manager.*
	- *They can quickly draft proposals and use templates, cutting proposal creation time by 50%.*
- ***Informed Decision Making***
	- *Syntra provides an overview of updated resources, ensuring delegates have all necessary context at their disposal.*
	- *Integration with OptimismDAO's calendar helping delegates stay up to date with community calls, office hours and seasons timelines.*
- ***Cross-DAO Management***
	- *For delegates involved in multiple DAOs, Syntra provides a unified interface without the need of switching between platforms. This also lower the barrier to entry of external DAO actors*"

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Syntra contributed to Optimism Governance since its  **private alpha release in late August**  and  **public alpha release in early September**.

## Users:
### OptimismDAO delegates
-   **Newcomers**: Syntra lowered barriers to entry by simplifying proposal drafting, commenting, voting, and governance analysis.
-   **Professional teams**: It streamlined internal coordination with role-based access and tracking features.

As of October 8th, Syntra has:

-   **209 total logins**
-   **33 MAU**: 33 active Optimism sessions since Sept (Month to date). 
	- **Active**: at least 1 Draft created.
-   Users from  **5 different countries** to date.
-   Currently also being used by SEEDGov for drafting.

More information regarding activity is available in the [Google Drive link](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1TZWtb_Q67hwqBHNGpgT4V7HocAs1LNKT?usp=sharing).

name: FrameMaker
description:
FrameMaker - Tilda in the frames world of Warpcast. Our goal is to make it easy to create frames for users who don't know coding.

FrameMaker allows you to create frames to delegate votes in the Optimism chain, making it easy to attract delegates, participate in governance, and significantly increase audience engagement in the ecosystem.

Our project was created by active top 100 delegates (https://vote.optimism.io/delegates/0x03dde7b6c372bc6c748ae1af65497b74a70492fa) and Optimism ecosystem ambassadors. 

*More than 600 people have already created over 1,500 frames.

links.name: Our users
links.description: Here you can see unique users and content created using FrameMaker.

links.name: Templates
links.description: We offer of frames through which it is possible to delegate OP.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer: We have created templates for creating frames for delegating tokens. By doing so, we attracted more users from Warpcast and made it easier for delegates. More: https://x.com/zefirium_crypto/status/1795062923720573226

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: The tool is most useful for delegates who are actively creating content on Warpcast. Our tool also attracted good organic growth in Optimism, whose chain we were the first to implement in FrameMaker, and our template was the first to create a delegation pool in OP.

links.name: Token House participation and incentives: Season 5 (Cycle 16-19)
links.description:
This report was designed as a snapshot of governance in Season 5, capturing key data on delegate participation and offering a condensed overview of Optimism's governance. It analyzes the Collective's evolution, from the expansion of Councils to a review of Missions V2. 

Additionally it served as a guide for the Foundation to determine the Retro Delegate Rewards for Season 5. The report presents not only quantitative data on governance effectiveness but also critical insights into the observed changes.

Proof of impact: https://gov.optimism.io/t/season-5-missions-v2-retrospective/8103

links.name: Big Picture: The Grants Council
links.description: This report provides a detailed retrospective on the work and impact of the Grants Council over the past three seasons within Optimismâ€™s governance. It highlights the Council's evolution from a governance experiment to a persistent structure, focusing on its role in streamlining grant distribution, improving fund management, and enhancing transparency. The report compiles public forum data to offer a chronological and quantifiable view of the Grants Council's work, including its structure, budget allocations, and the results achieved in each season. It also provides insights into governance processes, making it easier for delegates and new participants to understand the Councilâ€™s significance and influence on Optimism's ecosystem.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more
Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We conducted 2 researches that served as a reference for measuring participation in Governance:

Token House Participation and Incentives: Season 5 (Cycles 16-19), captures essential data on delegate participation and provides a condensed overview of governance during Season 5. It analyzes the Collective's evolution, highlighting significant findings such as a increase in mission proposals and a rise in active delegate participation, while noting a decline in mission approval rates, which may suggest a more rigorous selection process. 

Big Picture: The Grants Council, documents the evolution of the Grants Council, emphasizing its transition from a governance experiment to a vital structure within Optimism. This report details the Council's efforts to streamline grant distribution, enhance transparency, and improve fund management, offering a chronological and quantifiable perspective on its activities, structure, budget allocations, and results over the seasons.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer: The Token House Participation and Incentives served as a guide for the Foundation to determine the Retro Delegate Rewards for Season 5. While the Grants Council report was included as part of the govNERDs contribution path.

name: Developer Advisory Board (Season 5, Jan to June 2024)
description:
The Developer Advisory Board was launched as an experiment in Season 5, with the mandate of supporting the Collective with technical decision making, including advising the grants council on Mission Requests, applications and the completion of technical milestones.

The original post outlining the logic can be found here: https://gov.optimism.io/t/developer-advisory-board/6892

subcategory: Councils, Commissions and Advisory Boards; NERD programs focused exclusively on core governance responsibilities (GovNERDs)::This includes Security Council, Grants Council, Developer Advisory Board, Code of Conduct Council, Anticapture Commission, Collective Feedback Commissions and GovNERDs.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 5: Sept 28th 2023 - May 8th 2024

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
There were three goals for the DAB in Season 5, as laid out in the [initial forum post](https://gov.optimism.io/t/developer-advisory-board/6892):

1) Assess and approve Delegate Mission Request 13 drafts based on their technical merits 
2) Aid the Grants Council in assessing approved Delegate Mission Requests and Mission Applications 13 under Intent #1
3) Advise the Grants Council in assessing the completion of technical milestones

Additionally, there was one implicit goal:

4) Act as a test run to determine whether the DAB is a useful part of Optimism Governance, explore additional ways to help, and formalize processes for future seasons.

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
On the explicit goals:
- All Mission Requests were reviewed by multiple DAB members, who provided that input to the community in order to determine the right MRs to fund.
- All applications to the Grants Council under Intent #1 received feedback from 2+ DAB members to help better allocate funds. 
- Additionally, the DAB expanded our scope to provide input on all requested applications, not just Intent #1, a learning that has carried over to future seasons.
- The DAB also began to give feedback on the funding amount, which resulted in 100k+ OP being saved by governance due to more appropriate funding.

Additionally, on the implicit goal, the experiment of having a Developer Advisory Board was a great success. It was renewed for Season 6 with an expanded scope, and has continued to deliver important results.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer: Lawyerd's platform empowered the Optimism community to report scams, fraud, and brand violations, significantly improving transparency and accountability within the ecosystem. By integrating with the OP Stack, Lawyerd enabled more efficient community-driven governance, allowing participants to flag violations, protect their favorite projects, and earn rewards for contributing to ecosystem safety. Our platform actively supported decentralized governance by reducing fraud and scams that harm community trust, making Optimism a safer and more secure environment for builders and users alike.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: The most significant beneficiaries of Lawyerd's tooling are the Optimism governance participants, including protocol developers, brand owners, and community members. Developers benefit from reduced risks of scams undermining their projects, and brands are better protected against counterfeiters. Community members benefit by being incentivized to participate actively in governance by reporting violations, thereby creating a safer and more transparent environment across the Optimism ecosystem.

name: Impact Calculator Prototype
description:
The Impact Calculator is a draft project idea that the BuidlGuidl picked up to help the Optimism Foundation in trying out the concept of values-based metric voting before they put it into action in RF4. This build demonstrated the potential of this approach while also raising awareness of pitfalls. 

We worked closely with Jonas of the Optimism Foundation to try different solutions and work through challenges as they arose. 

Jonas can be quoted with the following statement in regards to this contribution:
"The Impact Calculator tool played a crucial role in experimenting with metrics-based voting, significantly shaping the design of Retro Funding 4. By providing practical insights into the implementation of metrics-based voting, it accelerated the development process and contributed to a more effective and informed design."

name: Tribuni Telegram Bot
description:
Who We Are

Tribuni was born out of the ETH Denver hackathon, spearheaded by a team of decentralized governance practitioners. Our founding members include delegates from Blockchain@USC actively participating in Optimism's governance. With expertise spanning software engineering, product design, and product management across both Web2 and crypto landscapes, our diverse team is dedicated to enhancing the delegate experience.

Our Story

Being a delegate requires constantly staying up-to-date due to the sheer volume of information that needs to be digested. Before Tribuni, we experienced firsthand the challenges of managing extensive data and keeping track of vital governance activities. To address this pain point, we engaged with a wide range of delegates from groups such as 404DAO, Brichis, PGov, Launamu, FranklinDAO, etc. Their insights and feedback inspired us to build a tool tailored specifically for delegates like them.

Our Solution

Delegates are the cornerstone of Optimism's governance system. Active and well-informed delegates lead to resilient and sound governance. However, delegates need to process a lot of information and often find it challenging to stay up-to-date. We are humans after all.

To help delegates stay active and well-informed, our team launched Tribuniâ€”a free Telegram mini-app built exclusively for delegates. Tribuni sends quality AI-generated proposal summaries, vote reminders, and OP forum activity digests directly via Telegram. This ensures that delegates never miss a vote or an important discussion within the OP ecosystem, as long as they're connected to Telegram.

Impact

As of September 2024, Tribuni proudly supports 28 OP delegate profiles, encompassing a staggering 28,217,127 votes combined. This substantial vote power not only surpasses Optimism's 26 million quorum but also underscores Tribuni's pivotal role in the governance ecosystem. Our platform serves 38 dedicated Optimism subscribers, including influential entities like PGOV, blockchain@USC, 404DAO, PGov, Gauntlet, Tane Gov, etc who manage multiple delegate memberships. Through Tribuni, we help them analyzed 1,113 posts across 186 forum topics, ensuring they remain well-informed and proactive in decision-making. By seamlessly integrating into their workflows, Tribuni has become an indispensable tool, empowering delegates to govern more effectively and maintain the resilience of Optimism's governance structure.

name: DAOstar
description: DAOstar is the non-profit standards body for DAOs.

github.name: DAOstar repository
github.description: Contains code related to EIP-4824 registration factories, indexers, daoURI templates & reference implementations; list of all DAOIPs; DAO Attestation framework, documentation; and deployments.

grants.details: Builder grant involving the development of an attestation list schema specifically designed for DAOs, a web platform for displaying attestations made using this schema to any address, and the necessary infrastructure for deploying new instances of the platform.
EIP-4824: Governance standards for the Optimism ecosystem

links.name: EIP-4824 Adoption by Optimism Collective (registration contract)
links.description: The Optimism Foundation deployed an EIP-4824 registration contract on Optimism mainnet, publishing a daoURI for the collective. This creates a single source of truth on the OP Collective, including data on governance proposals, delegates, contracts and documentation. Here is the published daoURI: https://ipfs.io/ipfs/Qmcqo4jTGrBxHxUXViWu7Z3NzucDk7y1RZZPjGJzswU8SZ

links.name: EIP-4824 Adoption by Optimism Collective (using EAS)
links.description: The Optimism Foundation published a daoURI for the OP collective, using the EIP-4824 schema deployed on EAS in Optimism mainnet. This creates a single source of truth on the OP Collective, including data on governance proposals, delegates, contracts and documentation. The reason for publishing daoURI via multiple sources (EAS and registration contract) is to showcase the ease of adopting the standard, and to test out the different adoption pathways available for all DAOs on Optimism. Here is the published daoURI: https://ipfs.io/ipfs/Qmcqo4jTGrBxHxUXViWu7Z3NzucDk7y1RZZPjGJzswU8SZ

links.name: Hosted endpoints and serivces necessary for Optimism Collective's daoURI
links.description: Hosted endpoints and serivces necessary for Optimism Collective's daoURI

links.name: EAS pathway to publish daoURI
links.description: Deployed a schema on EAS to publish daoURI, integrated it with the frontend form and explorer (at daostar.org), and updated docs to include this pathway.

links.name: DAO Schema Registry on EAS
links.description: Authored DAOIP-7 (Attestation Schema Registry for EAS), which is a registry of schemas on Ethereum Attestation Service, conforming to the DAO Attestation Standard. The registry is deployed on Optimism mainnet. The specification can be found here: https://github.com/metagov/daostar/blob/main/DAOIPs/daoip-7.md

links.name: DAO Attestation List
links.description: Built a proof-of-concept web-app that makes it easy for projects to adopt DAOIP-7 standard. All attestations are issued on Optimism, through the schema registry listed above.

links.name: Snapshot's EIP-4824 Integration
links.description: We enhanced Snapshot's EIP-4824 membersURI and proposalsURI to include more detailed information about a DAO's members and proposals. This upgrade enriches the daoURI of all DAOs in the Optimism ecosystem that rely on Snapshot.

links.name: State of DAOs Report focused on Asia
links.description: DAOstar worked with writers and communities embedded in Japan, Singapore, Taiwan, Korea amd Greater China on reports to cover the state of DAOs in Asia. Our findings pave a way forward for local communities to collaborate with global DAOs like Optimism to scale localized impact.

links.name: The DAO Policy Trilemma
links.description: This report, authored at DAOstar by the top experts on DAO regulation, makes two core recommendations to jurisdictions considering on how to address the policy issues and opportunities of DAOs. It will be incredible beneficial to the Optimism Collective, as well as other DAOs on Optimism, as the piece encourages jurisdictions to set suitable passive criteria for DAO legal recognition rather than requiring a DAO to actively register in their jurisdiction. DAOs often already publish verifiable, registration-like data through interfaces like EIP-4824. They should be able to use this data to prove their default legal status.

links.name: Legislative hearings on proposed DAO laws, Japan
links.description: Joni Pirovich, lead of the regulatory interoperability working group within DAOstar, appeared at the Japanese legislative hearings on proposed DAO laws in March 2024 on behalf of DAOstar, and helped bring additional context on DAOs to the hearing.

name: Attest Fest
description: Creating attestations should be easy! Attest Fest is a tool that allows you to batch create EAS attestations using only one Ethereum transaction. impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The OP foundation and Retro Funding have been some of the most active Attest Fest users through retropgf rounds 3, 4 and 5.

Attest Fest has been used to support various aspects of the retro funding process, including batch creating attestations for guest voters, citizens as well as assigning governance roles.

Attest Fest makes the process of creating those attestations simple by allowing uploading of CSV files from spreadsheets with attestation data.

name: OP Badgeholder Analysis and Dashboard
description: This project works to provide a comprehensive understanding of OP Badgeholder's On Chain activity and how it compares to the activity of active Optimism/Ethereum users. In a publicly accessible Dune dashboard, we analyze Badgeholder characteristics including their relative rates of activity on and off the Superchain, participation in governance, use of NFTs and smart contract deployments, and presence on social apps like Farcaster. This analysis provides OP governance with the information they need to continue equitably and effectively expanding the citizenry.

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance
Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We have created a comprehensive analysis of Optimism Badgeholder's onchain activity vs a control group of active non-Badgeholders. In particular, we looked at transaction activity across chains, involvement in social apps (Farcaster, Lens, Friendtech), participation in other DAOs (Arbitrum, Uniswap, ENS) and the deployment of smart contracts and NFTs. 

Something to note: although it is true that not all citizens use their Badgeholder address for other onchain activity, we found that a significant amount did and we discuss the implications of this constraint in the report.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
The Optimism Foundation. This work was requested directly by the Foundation in order to get a better understanding of Optimism Badgeholders vs â€œnormalâ€ Ethereum users. In their own words: â€œIn order to confidently expand the Citizenry, we need to have a baseline understanding of the current Badgeholder group. Our goal is to get a better understanding of the Badgeholder group based on their onchain activity compared with the onchain activity of other active Optimism/Ethereum users.â€

In addition, the entire Optimism Collective has benefitted from the transparency provided by this publicly available work. It's open source nature sets the stage for others to conduct further research and expand upon our results.

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We wanted to understand the rounds scoring mechanism given the totals and numbers reported did not make sense as an applicant.

In our round analysis. We extracted the raw excel data and and transformed them into formats typically used in data science (machine learning).

In doing so we were able to create a visual representation of the scoring for the round. We uncovered (known) shortcomings of the platform and were able to provide the collective information in an easy to understand format.

links.name: The DAO Policy Trilemma
links.description: This report, authored at DAOstar by the top experts on DAO regulation, makes two core recommendations to jurisdictions considering on how to address the policy issues and opportunities of DAOs. It will be incredible beneficial to the Optimism Collective, as well as other DAOs on Optimism, as the piece encourages jurisdictions to set suitable passive criteria for DAO legal recognition rather than requiring a DAO to actively register in their jurisdiction. DAOs often already publish verifiable, registration-like data through interfaces like EIP-4824. They should be able to use this data to prove their default legal status.

links.name: Legislative hearings on proposed DAO laws, Japan

name: Pairwise
description:
Pairwise was designed to make voting to distribute Retro Funding simple and fun. Pairwise is an open-source, off-chain voting dapp (like Snapshot) that streamlines community signaling by letting users select between just two options and then aggregating their choices into a quantifiable result.
Pairwise is designed to be user-friendly and intuitive, allowing users to make many simple choices and then the algorithm behind the scenes pumps out a final ranking for them to adjust or approve. 

* RF3: Served as an alternative tool for creating lists and subcategories of 600+ projects.
* RF4: Ran its own independent experiment involving all stakeholders to signal how to distribute RF promoting project discovery with pseudonymous voting.
* RF5: After great work on RF4, was invited to be a fun voting option to gamify and simplify the badgeholder decision making process. Allowing Badgeholders to create their ballot by comparing projects.

github.description: The open-source repository for Pairwise in Retro Funding 3, featuring a galaxy-themed frontend where badgeholders could rank projects and submit their ballots.

github.name: Pairwise RF 3 Backend
github.description: The open-source repository for Pairwise in Retro Funding 3, containing the algorithm and backend work necessary to power the ranking system.

grants.details: Token House approved this grant with the goal of enhancing the RetroPGF process by using a fun and interactive UX for voting. Pairwise implements proven ranking algorithms, similar to chess and football, to help badgeholders efficiently signal impact.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
We developed Pairwise for RF3, and introduced categories to make the impact measurement in the Retro Funding more organic and manageable.
In RF3, 185 users engaged, 27 badgeholders using their key
In RF4, we expanded into a community-wide experiment using pseudonymous voting with zk-tech. This allowed all stakeholdersâ€”badgeholders, token holders, recipients, and delegatesâ€”to participate freely without pressure and promote project discovery. Here you can find the final results, and our blog conclusions for more details on our outcomes.
The feedback from RF4 was very positive, leading to our invitation to build together with Optimism for RF5. For this round, we developed a star rating system, enabling participants to assign stars to projects before comparing them. This system grouped projects into tiers, significantly reducing the number of comparisons required.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
The main target when developing the product were badgeholders, who now can use Pairwise, to rank the Retro Funding projects in a fun way that promotes project discovery. However, the entire Optimism community, including delegates, token holders, and recipients, also gained through their participation in the Pairwise Retro Funding experiment, offering them the chance to discover impactful projects and bring more visibility to emerging initiatives. Projects benefited from increased exposure to potential users. Pairwise also sparks discussions  by comparing its results to official ones, fostering deeper insights and driving more meaningful participation and progress to decentralization.
To incentivize engagement, we distributed 4,000 OP as rewards giving a 100OP to 40 lucky winners, 10 on each stakeholder group participating in Pairwise.

name: Optimism Delegate Frame on Farcaster
description:
The â€œOptimism Delegate Frameâ€ on Farcaster is a useful tool that makes OP delegation easy and accessible. With this frame, users can quickly check who their OP delegate is and re-delegate their voting power if they choose.

It starts with the â€œCheck My Delegateâ€ button, showing key info like wallet address, OP balance, and the current delegate. A user can then pick a new delegate by entering their wallet address, ENS, or Farcaster handle and confirming through their wallet.

Once complete, the user gets a confirmation with transaction details and can share it with others on Farcaster. The tool integrates Optimismâ€™s delegation function, making it straightforward for anyone to participate in governance.

The frame is made by Tempe Techie and Tekr, both delegates and builders in the Optimism ecosystem. We are also very active on Farcaster, which is why we decided to build a tool that is useful to both us and others on Farcaster.

subcategory: Governance Tooling::Tools which are used by Delegates or Citizens participate in Optimism Governance  tools which are used by Delegates and/or Citizens asuch as voting clients. Tools which support delegates and citizens insights into governance performance and history

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
Many people donâ€™t often think about whom they delegate their tokens to, or whether they have delegated them at all. Our frame reminds users of the delegation option, allowing them to review and choose a different delegate. 

Everything happens within the Farcaster app, with no need to go outside of it, making the process more convenient. The frame makes delegation easy and encourages people to think about governance.

The tool is in the form of a frame, which is a Farcaster invention. Itâ€™s essentially a link preview on steroids. Frames can include buttons and text fields that allow users to interact directly with them. A frame is basically a mini-app within Farcaster.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer:
Citizens and delegates active on Farcaster have benefited the most from the Optimism Delegate Frame. 

Delegates can share pre-filled frames with their information, making it easy for users to delegate to them with just a few clicks. This system allows delegates to promote themselves while reminding citizens to check their current delegate and switch if they choose. 

Since these frames are shared publicly on Farcaster, they help raise awareness about Optimism governance and encourage more users to engage with the delegation process.

links.name: Big Picture: The Grants Council
links.description: This report provides a detailed retrospective on the work and impact of the Grants Council over the past three seasons within Optimismâ€™s governance. It highlights the Council's evolution from a governance experiment to a persistent structure, focusing on its role in streamlining grant distribution, improving fund management, and enhancing transparency. The report compiles public forum data to offer a chronological and quantifiable view of the Grants Council's work, including its structure, budget allocations, and the results achieved in each season. It also provides insights into governance processes, making it easier for delegates and new participants to understand the Councilâ€™s significance and influence on Optimism's ecosystem.

impactStatement.answer:
We conducted 2 researches that served as a reference for measuring participation in Governance:

Token House Participation and Incentives: Season 5 (Cycles 16-19), captures essential data on delegate participation and provides a condensed overview of governance during Season 5. It analyzes the Collective's evolution, highlighting significant findings such as a increase in mission proposals and a rise in active delegate participation, while noting a decline in mission approval rates, which may suggest a more rigorous selection process. 

Big Picture: The Grants Council, documents the evolution of the Grants Council, emphasizing its transition from a governance experiment to a vital structure within Optimism. This report details the Council's efforts to streamline grant distribution, enhance transparency, and improve fund management, offering a chronological and quantifiable perspective on its activities, structure, budget allocations, and results over the seasons.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The Lighthouse native mobile app makes it easy for Citizens and Delegates to participate in Optimism governance. We built support for Optimism's custom Governor contract, which enabled us to add multiple powerful new features:

1. We've added real time push notifications of new proposal and voting activity. 

2. We've added the ability to vote on proposals, on-chain, natively from within the Lighthouse app. 

3. We also pulled in on-chain comments and displayed them within the app, to surface community sentiment around proposals for users.

4. Our interactive Farcaster Frames integration enables on-chain proposals and comments to be shared, further increasing awareness and participation in the social media space.

This all works together to provide a powerful and feature-complete alternative client for users who wish to vote on the go.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: Token holders, delegates and followers benefit by Optimism being on Lighthouse. Even users who do not hold Optimism tokens are able to follow core Optimism proposal activity, making Optimism governance more accessible throughout the ecosystem.

name: OP Governance Trackor
description:
I was ex governance co-lead at blockchain@USC (delegating on behalf of a16z) at the OP Collective. At the time, I realized there were no public accountability for delegates meanwhile lots of them receive huge amount of votes. And to help the collective better monitor delegates, especially the top 100 of them, I consult with people like Justine (OP head of gov), Ross (a16z), Michael Silberling (OP Data), and lots of delegates on the metrics to track for governance. 

Thus, I created 2 public dune dashboards for the OP Collective to track the governance "performance" of its delegates. One is for the top 100 delegates. The other is for the a16z Optimism Delegates (including university clubs, professional delegate groups, and a few crypto native delegates. They track votes participations, voting powers, voting rationales, and other relevant metrics (on both individual level and the aggregate level). It help the OP collective to identify active and inactive delegates (with lots of voting power) to reward accordingly and conduct liquid delegation when performance degrades. It also help the delegators  such as a16z's and others to know which smaller voting power delegates are active in governance: offering them a platform for delegators to know more about them.

links.name: OP Governance Tracker (General)
links.description: The Optimism Governance Dashboard provides real-time tracking of proposals and participation statistics for the Optimism Collective. By visualizing metrics like total proposals, votes cast, and voter involvement over time, the dashboard enables bi-cameral members to analyze trends and delegate activity in Optimism's on-chain governance system. It provides public accountability towards delegates with huge voting powers, identifying active ones and inactive ones and facilitating retro rewarding and liquid delegations respectively.

links.name: OP Governance Tracker (a16z Delegates)
links.description: This dashboard tracks the governance performance for a16z delegates at the Optimism Collective. It provides public accountability towards delegates with huge voting powers, identifying active ones and inactive ones and facilitating retro rewarding and liquid delegations respectively.

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
- Voter turnout: delegate participation as of last update
- Non-conformity: how many delegates have their "own" opinion when voting 
- Voting Bloc power over time: tracks the top100 or individual voting power over time
- Voting Cost: total gas cost across votes and average gas cost per delegate
- Inactive Delegates: who are they and how many votes they have
- Underrated Delegates: who have little voting power but has been consistently voting and has high-non-conformity score
- Statistics on Delegate Profiling: delegates who are self delegates vs those who have more than 1 delegators

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
Professional Delegators such as a16z: to monitor performance of its delegates at OP Collective. With the dashboard that I created, they know which delegates are active and which are not contributing in governance. With the data in mind, it will facilitate liquid-delegations for their next cohort. 

OP Foundation: identify active OP delegates who are amongst the top 100 ones and conduct retro-reward for active participants accordingly. 

OP Collective Delegators: with the underrated delegate lists, they can support them by delegating OPs to these delegates and let them grow from bottom up.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
The Lighthouse native mobile app makes it easy for Citizens and Delegates to participate in Optimism governance. We built support for Optimism's custom Governor contract, which enabled us to add multiple powerful new features:

1. We've added real time push notifications of new proposal and voting activity. 

2. We've added the ability to vote on proposals, on-chain, natively from within the Lighthouse app. 

3. We also pulled in on-chain comments and displayed them within the app, to surface community sentiment around proposals for users.

4. Our interactive Farcaster Frames integration enables on-chain proposals and comments to be shared, further increasing awareness and participation in the social media space.

This all works together to provide a powerful and feature-complete alternative client for users who wish to vote on the go.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: Token holders, delegates and followers benefit by Optimism being on Lighthouse. Even users who do not hold Optimism tokens are able to follow core Optimism proposal activity, making Optimism governance more accessible throughout the ecosystem.

name: Optimism Grant analytics: Grant3
description:
Grant3 is the most Comprehensive Grants database for Optimism. With Over 1078 Projects and 134 Million OP distributed through Optimism are manually tracked on Grant3.

Problem:
Currently data about Grantees of OP Collective is scattered across multiple different platforms like OP Governance Forum, Charmverse and RetroPGF Platform. There is no single platform where members of the OP collective can easily view and track Grantees with their grant details.

With Grant3, viewers can easily view details of all the grantees in a single place making it easy for tracking, collaboration and verification, fostering deeper collaboration within the OP Community.

Features of Grant3 incude
- Grantee Database: A database with more than 134M OP Tracked and 1000+ grantee projects tracked.
- Grants Timeline: a unified timeline informing potential applicants about past and upcoming grant programs on Optimism
- Dashboard : Single point of information on all things grants for Optimism
- Articles: In-depth information about Optimism and its grant programs
- OP Analytics: Data sources to dig deeper into the OP ecosystem

links.name: OP Grants Bulletin Board
links.description: A single source of information for all current, upcoming Grants programs and announcements in Optimism. All the ongoing grants are listed in a timeline format for users to find out the current opportunities they can apply to within Optimism.

links.name: OP Grant Articles
links.description: Detailed information on various events happening within the OP grants domain. The articles give users a complete understanding of the Grants processes and helps them with granular details.

links.name: OP Analytics
links.description: A generalized data aggregation on various statistics for the OP Ecosystem.

links.name: OP Grantee Database
links.description:
The most Comprehensive database on OP grants with 1078 Projects tracked and 134 Million OP Tokens distributed. Our Grantee database aggregates data on OP Grants from multiple platforms like OP Forums, Charmverse and RetroPGF. 

The intuitive layout and functionality of the Database makes it easy to filter grantees based on various parameters like Cycles (Cycle 27, Cycle 26, Cycle 19 and more), Grant Types (RetroPGF, Growth experiments, Builders, Intents, Audits), Grant Amount (Under 50K, over 50K) and tags (Superchain, data, infrastructure, NFT) and more. The search functionality provides additional feature to directly search for Grantee projects

links.name: OP Grants Dashboard
links.description: A single point of information for all statistics about OP Grants. Users can find the number of Projects granted, the amount of OP granted. Furthermore users can find more information about each Cycle of the Grants council, its number of winners and total OP distributed for the particular cycle

subcategory: Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
Grant Allocation, Grant Program Analytics and Grantee Tracker:

The OP grant tracker is the largest data source for Optimism Grants, which in turn is one of the largest data source for Grantee details in the Web3. Till date the project has tracked more than 1078 grantees with a total allocation of more than 134 Million OP. The tracker adds grant awardees on a continuous  basis with data on the latest Cycle grantees also available for users to view and analyze.

Currently, the data on OP Grantees is highly fragmented, scattered over multiple platforms like Charmverse, OP Forums and RetroPGF Interface. There is no unified interface for users to view data on all grantees that have received OP from the Treasury.

Beyond the numbers, the tracker presents the data on grantees in a simple and intuitive interface, enabling users to easily narrow down their research based on various parameters like Grants cycles, grant type, grant size and tags.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
1. Delegates in decision making: Delegates do not have the bandwidth to do in-depth research and make informed decisions on Grants when the data is so scattered. The OP Grants tracker makes it easy to compare performances of various Grant cycles with qualitative and quantitative measures.

2. Grants Council Members in Grantee tracking: For each cycle, get a list of grantees, their application links and granular details related to their application. Our research enables GC Members to track projects that have ceased operations despite winning grants or have not performed up to the expectations, facilitating learning for future grant screening.

3. Potential Grant Applicants in grants research: Potential applicants search grantees with similar area of focus (defi, data, infra, etc) and analyze successful applications. Furthermore, applicants get a better picture of the rubrics and reporting requirements, giving them more chances of success.

4. OP Collective Members in general analytics

name: Optimism Governance in Costa Rica
description:
Inbest has been a leader in the region for Optimism Governance, focused on delivering Web3 education in Spanish and establishing Optimism's presence in Costa Rica since 2023. We've actively contributed to the Superchain and its governance model. The country's first university blockchain course was created as part of a Token House mission we applied for and successfully completed: [Integrate Optimism Governance into University Module].

We have been leading especially in S5 and S6, through Inbest-sponsored OP Days, talks at universities, digital content, and more. Thanks to this S5's mission to integrate Optimism governance into university modules, we've sparked interest across students, users, and major universities.

You can find this detailed syllabus in an easier to read format along with slides and presentations in the links bellow and in the optimism  forum.

grants.details:
Governance and RGPF into Universities
Country's first university blockchain module

InBest carried the entire mission from the application, research & creation to organizing, teaching, and grading. All human hours, expenses and costs were covered by us
agalan@ucenfotec.ac.cr

links.name: Optimism Governance into University modules
links.description:
The first university module on blockchain technology at a national level was made possible thanks to optimism,  our prior knowledge, experience, relationships, work, and support from the grants council. 

Everything aligned for us to take on the mission of bringing Optimism governance to universities in Costa Rica.

I, Alberto, team leader at InBest and educator at CENFOTEC University (agalan@ucenfotec.ac.cr), initiated the application for this mission, bringing the opportunity to CENFOTEC students. It's important to note that not only CENFOTEC students were accepted but also students from other universities, the course was held at CENFOTEC's facilities. 

Thanks to this win-win collaboration, CENFOTEC positioned itself as a tech leader in the region and attracted new attention, while Optimism established itself in Costa Rica as a growing ecosystem with many opportunities.

However, it was thanks to the joint effort of the InBest team that all of this was possible. The team dedicated countless hours to research, work, creating contacts, and everything necessary to make this a reality. On behalf of the entire Costa Rican community, we are immensely grateful to the Optimism Foundation and the grants committee for trusting us with this responsibility, and to CENFOTEC University for fully supporting the initiative. Special thanks to all the team contributors as well.

To avoid overwhelming this message with numerous links, weâ€™ve decided to publish a single link to the Optimism governance forum, where everything is meticulously documentedâ€”dates, links, photos, videos, contracts, and more.

This two-month course consisted of four modules and 13 sessions, with four educators covering their areas of expertise. The course included assignments, quizzes, exams, and a final group project!

We also took the initiative to organize a small hackathon called "From Costa Rica to the Superchain," where students competed in Jockey Race and prepared a short pitch for the forum. Specific details about this will be covered in a separate section.

100% of the funds received from the Growth Grant were distributed among the students. All additional expenses, such as promotion, software, gas fees, content creation, etc., were covered by InBest. It is important to mention that none of the educators or special guests received any compensation for their time or preparation for the classes. Details on how student rewards were distributed, including addresses, links, and on-chain proof, are documented in the linked forum post.

Thanks to these efforts, we are now in contact with other universities that are taking notice of what's happening.

Everything has been documented and is publicly available for anyone to replicate in the future.

links.name: From Costa Rica to the Superchain
links.description:
"From Costa Rica to the Superchain" is an initiative that emerged from the university module. We organized a small hackathon for the students, where they had to pitch their projects in a virtual meeting to both peers and teachers, followed by a fun joke race!

Each project had to include an MVP with a contract deployed on OPsepolia. The presented projects were:

- Merkle Tree Airdrop
- Web3 Affiliate Marketing
- Web3 Grades Manager
- Fitness Dapp
- Web3 Bets
- Decentralized WAZE
- Superchain Donations
- Web3 Gaming

Full details of each project can be found in the forum post.

Even though the module and all sessions were conducted in Spanish, we held this hackathon in English, pushing students to pitch in English as well. This was done to prepare them for future opportunities, most of which are in English like the missions request, and to take them out of their comfort zones. It was encouraging to see students with limited English skills successfully present their projects and even post them on the governance forum as short video pitches.

One student, Fabricio, has already applied for a Web3 gaming mission. Although his mission wasnâ€™t approved this time, it's a clear sign of the module and hackathon's positive outcomes. Some participants have joined the Superchain hackathon, while others are now involved in the Base Latam hackathon.

You can also find more information in the forum post linked to the application, where all the assignments completed during the module are documented.

This was discussed with the Grant Council before applying, as the university wasn't equipped with the knowledge to run the course, and Inbest team took full responsibility for its execution.

links.name: OP Day
links.description:
To avoid sharing numerous links for every event, we've decided to publish the links to the governance forum where all progress has been properly documented with the dates.

In this forum topic, you'll find everything related to the OP Day initiative created by InBest. It began at the start of 2024 with the goal of growing the OP community in the country and educating people about Optimism governance, its technology, and the superchain.

- In February, we hosted a special Valentineâ€™s Day event featuring Optimism Red, targeting local communities. We invited Asoblockchain and Criptocantina to bring the Optimism ecosystem to them and showcase its opportunities. With around 50 attendees, we covered topics like an introduction to Optimism, governance, grants, RPGF, and OP airdrops for users. We also ran a "learn to earn" game with OP tokens as rewards. The event's expenses, such as the venue, decoration, and food, were covered by the InBest team. We also created videos and photos to promote it on social media. everything is on the forum.

During this OP initiative, we onboarded Robert, founder of CheckMyTicket (now Hallos.io), who migrated from Polygon and Arbitrum to the Optimism mainnet. Heâ€™s now a key figure in the Base LatAm initiative. This first event served as a test, and we issued NFT tickets to all attendees. Full details are available on the forum post.

- In March, we held a virtual OP Day focused on governance and missions. It was a smaller event tailored to builders, and the idea to integrate Optimism governance into local university courses was born here. We had Pumbi, an Optimism ambassador, as a special guest, and the event was hosted on Hallos via the OP mainnet. Criptocantina also applied for a growth mission afterward, though it wasnâ€™t approved this time. Links to the presentation and NFTs are on the forum.

In addition to the virtual event, we also had a March event at CENFOTEC University, marking the first introduction of the OP ecosystem to a university. This laid the foundation for CENFOTEC becoming the home of the first blockchain university module in the country. Full details are on the forum post.

- In April, we headed to Sendero on the east side with Criptocantina. Alfredo Brolag led the presentation, and we partnered with Hallos.io to issue NFTs to attendees. At this event, Optimism's new intents for the next governance seasons were announced, and we highlighted these opportunities for our communities. I also announced my role as a delegate and invited attendees to participate in Token House governance. This event was also sponsored by InBest. Pictures, details, and NFTs are on the forum.

- In May, we continued with the mission of bringing the superchain to local communities. This time, we were invited to present at Telescoped, a community of Web2 developers. We introduced Optimism governance, grant missions, and RPGF opportunities to a new audience of developers in Costa Rica. The presentation was filmed and published on our YouTube channel to broaden its impact ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HIae-YbSdxk&list=PLjbGiMPlmBjsya5a8HMIKqaAnaurtUpZT&index=3&t=181s ). All the links, videos, pictures, and the presentation are documented on the forum.

- In June, we prepared for the mission to integrate governance into university modules. Alongside Robert, I presented at UNA, one of the countryâ€™s major universities, on blockchain technology and opportunities in the superchain. We invited attendees to sign up for the upcoming university module in CENFOTEC University, which helped achieve a 100% success rate since we were focusing on tech students and not just promoting the module with anyone who just wanted quick rewards in OP. Full details, links, and pictures are on the forum.

- in July and August we did not host OPDays, we were dedicated to the Optimism University Module at CENFOTEC, which will be covered separately.

- In September, we hosted another OP Day to maintain momentum after the university module. We held a graduation party for the 25 students who completed the module at Nucleo Sabana rooftop in the heart of San JosÃ©, with food and drinks. We also gave a brief presentation to continue educating the community. sponsored by inbest. Links, pictures, and all details are on the forum.

- October: TBA.

This year the Main ETH Event is using hallos.io on base chain to register the attendants and sell the tickets, this year the event will be hosted in CENFOTEC as a result of the relationship we have been growing, we have given discounts to the holders of the OP Day and the University Module NFTs, showcasing the use case of NFT ticketing and incentivizing holders to attend.

To support and complement our physical events and increase our reach, we have continued creating digital content to educate our growing audience on Optimism governance through InBest channels. For example, we drew inspiration for this video from one made in English by OP Michael: 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H91b6a9duxA&list=PLjbGiMPlmBjsya5a8HMIKqaAnaurtUpZT&index=2&t=224s

Creating the next generation of Optimism leaders, ensuring a robust future for the ecosystem!

We see Passport at the confluence of a best in class identity solution, backed by the most relevant and comprehensive data analysis toolset that also offers communities the ability to ascribe reputation.

subcategory: Grants Tooling::Tools which support the Token House mission process, including the operation of the grants council. Tools which power or support the Retro Funding process.

impactStatement.question: How did your infrastructure or tooling support Optimism Governance?
impactStatement.answer:
In collaboration with OSO, Passport XYZ's Humanity scores were used to better understand the likelihood of real humans that were interacting with projects over the last year. The goal was to determine which projects were driving spam/bot traffic versus which projects were driving real users to the Optimism ecosystem. 

These metrics and the analysis was used in the RPGF4 voting and review process, improving the understanding and (we believe) the outcome for voters by informing which projects were driving real humans, and organic users to the collective versus which were just bringing short term bots or spam users to the network (often low value and transient).

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from your infrastructure and tooling?
impactStatement.answer: Our infrastructure and tooling has benefited the Badgeholder community the most, through our support of the RPGF rounds. Although we have made humanity proofs available via Attestations for nearly a year now on Optimism, the real value of this work has come from the inclusion and integration with the badgeholder experience (and collaboration with OSO) when reviewing and voting for projects to receive rewards.

description: We are excited to introduce EVM Explorer, a powerful, open-source web interface designed to streamline the exploration and analysis of blockchain data across multiple EVM chains, including the Optimism ecosystem. EVM Explorer utilizes the BlockScout API and viem library to enable users to delve into transaction patterns, user behavior, and smart contract data, providing a versatile tool for efficient and insightful blockchain exploration.

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
EVM Explorer's analytics work provides valuable insights into the influence of smart contract behavior on governance processes, enhancing transparency and understanding of the impact of smart contracts on Optimism Governance.

Smart Contract Performance: Analyzing the performance and usage of smart contracts within the Optimism network to understand their impact on governance processes. This includes tracking metrics such as the number of interactions with specific contracts, the frequency of transactions, and the distribution of contract usage across different governance-related functions.

Governance-relevant Token Balances: Tracking and analyzing token balances that are relevant to governance, such as voting tokens or tokens used for delegating authority. This analysis sheds light on the distribution of voting power, governance-related events, and stakeholder engagement in governance decision-making.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer: The analytics work by EVM Explorer on smart contract behavior in Optimism Governance benefits various ecosystem stakeholders. Active governance participants gain insights into smart contract performance and token balances, aiding informed decision-making and effective participation. Governance teams leverage detailed analytics to assess governance mechanisms, identify areas for enhancement, and tailor strategies. Developers benefit from understanding user interactions with contracts, leading to improved contract efficiency. Token projects find value in analytics on token balances and distribution for assessing engagement and governance mechanisms. Researchers benefit from comprehensive analytics, deepening insights into governance processes and contributing to the governance community. Overall, EVM Explorer's analytics enhance transparency, understanding, and efficiency in Optimism Governance, benefiting stakeholders across the ecosystem.

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
Strategic Oversight: Ensuring alignment between governance practices and the organizationâ€™s strategic goals.
Risk Management: Identifying, assessing, and managing risks to safeguard the organizationâ€™s assets and reputation.
Compliance: Ensuring adherence to legal, regulatory, and ethical standards.
Stakeholder Engagement: Facilitating communication and collaboration among stakeholders to foster transparency and trust.
Performance Monitoring: Evaluating organizational performance and governance effectiveness to promote continuous improvement.
Policy Development: Creating and maintaining governance policies that reflect best practices

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
nhanced Strategic Alignment: By actively engaging with leadership to align governance practices with strategic objectives, the function can ensure that decisions support long-term goals.

Robust Risk Management: Implementing comprehensive risk assessment frameworks can help identify potential issues early, enabling proactive measures that protect the organization and enhance resilience.

Strengthened Compliance Framework: Regularly reviewing and updating compliance policies ensures that the organization stays ahead of regulatory changes, minimizing the risk of non-compliance.

Effective Stakeholder Engagement: By fostering open communication channels with stakeholders, the function can build trust and encourage collaborative decision-making, which enhances overall governance.

Continuous Performance Monitoring: Establishing metrics to evaluate governance effectiveness allows for ongoing assessment and refinement of practices, ensuring they remain relevant and impactful.

links.name: EIP-4824 Adoption by Optimism Collective (using EAS)
links.description: The Optimism Foundation published a daoURI for the OP collective, using the EIP-4824 schema deployed on EAS in Optimism mainnet. This creates a single source of truth on the OP Collective, including data on governance proposals, delegates, contracts and documentation. The reason for publishing daoURI via multiple sources (EAS and registration contract) is to showcase the ease of adopting the standard, and to test out the different adoption pathways available for all DAOs on Optimism. Here is the published daoURI: https://ipfs.io/ipfs/Qmcqo4jTGrBxHxUXViWu7Z3NzucDk7y1RZZPjGJzswU8SZ

links.name: State of DAOs Report focused on Asia
links.description: DAOstar worked with writers and communities embedded in Japan, Singapore, Taiwan, Korea amd Greater China on reports to cover the state of DAOs in Asia. Our findings pave a way forward for local communities to collaborate with global DAOs like Optimism to scale localized impact.

links.name: The DAO Policy Trilemma
links.description: This report, authored at DAOstar by the top experts on DAO regulation, makes two core recommendations to jurisdictions considering on how to address the policy issues and opportunities of DAOs. It will be incredible beneficial to the Optimism Collective, as well as other DAOs on Optimism, as the piece encourages jurisdictions to set suitable passive criteria for DAO legal recognition rather than requiring a DAO to actively register in their jurisdiction. DAOs often already publish verifiable, registration-like data through interfaces like EIP-4824. They should be able to use this data to prove their default legal status.

links.name: Legislative hearings on proposed DAO laws, Japan
links.description: Joni Pirovich, lead of the regulatory interoperability working group within DAOstar, appeared at the Japanese legislative hearings on proposed DAO laws in March 2024 on behalf of DAOstar, and helped bring additional context on DAOs to the hearing.

name: Developer Advisory Board (Season 5)
description:
The Developer Advisory Board was launched as an experiment in Season 5, with the mandate of supporting the Collective with technical decision making, including advising the grants council on Mission Requests, applications and the completion of technical milestones.

The original post outlining the logic can be found here: https://gov.optimism.io/t/developer-advisory-board/6892

subcategory: Councils, Commissions and Advisory Boards; NERD programs focused exclusively on core governance responsibilities (GovNERDs)::This includes Security Council, Grants Council, Developer Advisory Board, Code of Conduct Council, Anticapture Commission, Collective Feedback Commissions and GovNERDs.

impactStatement.question: In what season did your work take place
impactStatement.answer: Season 5: Sept 28th 2023 - May 8th 2024

impactStatement.question: What is the mandate of your Governance Leadership function?
impactStatement.answer:
There were three goals for the DAB in Season 5, as laid out in the [initial forum post](https://gov.optimism.io/t/developer-advisory-board/6892):

1) Assess and approve Delegate Mission Request 13 drafts based on their technical merits 
2) Aid the Grants Council in assessing approved Delegate Mission Requests and Mission Applications 13 under Intent #1
3) Advise the Grants Council in assessing the completion of technical milestones

Additionally, there was one implicit goal:

4) Act as a test run to determine whether the DAB is a useful part of Optimism Governance, explore additional ways to help, and formalize processes for future seasons.

impactStatement.question: How did your work achieve or exceed the mandate of your Governance Leadership Function?
impactStatement.answer:
On the explicit goals:
- All Mission Requests were reviewed by multiple DAB members, who provided that input to the community in order to determine the right MRs to fund.
- All applications to the Grants Council under Intent #1 received feedback from 2+ DAB members to help better allocate funds. 
- Additionally, the DAB expanded our scope to provide input on all requested applications, not just Intent #1, a learning that has carried over to future seasons.
- The DAB also began to give feedback on the funding amount, which resulted in 100k+ OP being saved by governance due to more appropriate funding.

Additionally, on the implicit goal, the experiment of having a Developer Advisory Board was a great success. It was renewed for Season 6 with an expanded scope, and has continued to deliver important results.

name: OP Badgeholder Analysis and Dashboard
description: This project works to provide a comprehensive understanding of OP Badgeholder's On Chain activity and how it compares to the activity of active Optimism/Ethereum users. In a publicly accessible Dune dashboard, we analyze Badgeholder characteristics including their relative rates of activity on and off the Superchain, participation in governance, use of NFTs and smart contract deployments, and presence on social apps like Farcaster. This analysis provides OP governance with the information they need to continue equitably and effectively expanding the citizenry.

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance
Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We have created a comprehensive analysis of Optimism Badgeholder's onchain activity vs a control group of active non-Badgeholders. In particular, we looked at transaction activity across chains, involvement in social apps (Farcaster, Lens, Friendtech), participation in other DAOs (Arbitrum, Uniswap, ENS) and the deployment of smart contracts and NFTs. 

Something to note: although it is true that not all citizens use their Badgeholder address for other onchain activity, we found that a significant amount did and we discuss the implications of this constraint in the report.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
The Optimism Foundation. This work was requested directly by the Foundation in order to get a better understanding of Optimism Badgeholders vs â€œnormalâ€ Ethereum users. In their own words: â€œIn order to confidently expand the Citizenry, we need to have a baseline understanding of the current Badgeholder group. Our goal is to get a better understanding of the Badgeholder group based on their onchain activity compared with the onchain activity of other active Optimism/Ethereum users.â€

In addition, the entire Optimism Collective has benefitted from the transparency provided by this publicly available work. It's open source nature sets the stage for others to conduct further research and expand upon our results.

name: Attacks on DAOs (Academic Research Project)
description:
We systematically analyze security threats to Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs) in an academic paper: https://drops.dagstuhl.de/entities/document/10.4230/LIPIcs.AFT.2024.28. In our paper, we focus on the various types of attacks they face. Specifically, we examine historical attacks on DAOs, theorized attack vectors, and potential attacks that were identified and mitigated through audits across different blockchain ecosystems. For each of these (potential) attacks, we describe and categorize the utilized attack vectors into four categories. Our analysis reveals that while many attacks on DAOs exploit the less tangible and more complex human dynamics involved in governance, audits tend to concentrate primarily on code and protocol vulnerabilities. To provide ongoing insights into the risks DAOs encounter, we maintain an up-to-date dataset at www.daoattacks.ethz.ch.

Additionally, we distill a set of key risk factors for DAOs and empirically examine the vulnerabilities of 26 DAOs, including the Token House of the Optimism DAO. We open-source the code used for this analysis. Finally, we propose mitigation strategies aimed at safeguarding DAOs against these vulnerabilities.

github.name: DAO Vulnerability
github.description: This repo provides the code to empirically assess the risk of various DAOs (including the Optimism DAO).

subcategory: Optimism Metagovernance research::Research that has provided relevant insight into the design of Optimism Governance
Optimism Governance related analytics::Analyses of the performance of Optimism governance, including governance participation, grant allocation and more

impactStatement.question: What aspects of Optimism Governance is your analytics work measuring?
impactStatement.answer:
We measure various aspects of the Optimism Token House to capture how susceptible it is to multiple risk factors we identify. These risk factors are (RF1) voter apathy, (RF2) high governance token liquidity, (RF3) large treasury, (RF4) inadequate configuration, (RF5) centralization, and (RF6) code uncertainties. For each of these risk factors, we identify multiple empirical measures that let us assess how vulnerable a DAO is. Note that we do this analysis not only for the Optimism Token House but also for another 25 DAOs in the Ethereum ecosystem.
 
We further created a data set of attacks on DAOs in the past, but none are directly related to Optimism Governance.

impactStatement.question: Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?
impactStatement.answer:
Our analytical work benefits two groups. The first group is protocols that use a DAO for their governance. They can use the dataset of attacks, as well as the empirical measures we identify to assess the vulnerability of their DAO and react if needed. The same holds for those protocols that want to switch to DAO governance, which can make some of these assessments before they make the switch.
 
Additionally, it benefits those who have a stake in the DAO (i.e., those who hold the token) to assess the vulnerability of the DAO.

name: Aragon
description: Aragon was founded in 2016 with the belief that the fate of humanity will be decided at the frontier of technological innovation and human collaboration. Aragon launched the first DAO Framework in 2017 which secures over $40 billion in TVL. Aragonâ€™s tech stack allows anyone to launch a DAO, enabling organizations to securely govern their protocols and assets onchain.

github.name: Aragon App Github
github.description: The Aragon App is a human-centered no-code interface that allows anyone to deploy and manage a DAO onchain. Anyone can deploy a delegate voting DAO or â€œmultisigâ€ DAO on five chains, in under 10 minutes. They can also mint ERC20Votes governance tokens. Participants can transparently find all of the information they need to participate, including membership, proposals, transactions, and settings. They can easily create and vote on complex onchain proposals with tools like the Smart Contract Composer and dApp Connect (allowing DAOs to interact with dApps like an EOA).

github.name: Aragon OSx Github
github.description: Aragon OSx is a DAO framework that allows developers to build, deploy, and evolve custom DAOs onchain. Governance logic is programmed into plugins, making custom and granular governance designs easier, faster, and safer to build. It allows organizations to build multi-body, multi-process, and multichain governance, tailored to their unique needs. Plugins can be installed, upgraded, and uninstalled, allowing DAOs to evolve over time, onchain, via their governance process. All DAOs built on Aragon OSx can benefit from the modularity of the framework, by easily installing open source plugins built by others.

grants.details: We've received a grant to build, together with RISC Zero, a cutting edge crosschain voting solution that will also be compatible with the OP stack. We've agreed to split the original grant amount with another project that applied, so a retro allocation could fill our building gap
